fields.title: About Us
fields.content:
al·pha geek

noun informal [from animal ethologists' alpha male]
  1.   the most technically accomplished or skillful person in some implied context
    Ask Larry, he's the alpha geek here.
  2.   a person who has great expertise in computing and related technology
    The alpha geeks are often a few years ahead of their time.

fields.title: Computer Services
fields.content:
We know how intimidating your computer can be, so let us help. Why spend the day trying to solve your tech problems when our experts can get you up and running in no time? Let us do the work so you can get on with your life. We'll even come to you ( DFW residents only)! Contact us NOW to schedule an appointment!

Need help when you're out of town? Don't panic. As long as you have a working internet connection, we still might be able to help. Simply schedule an appointment for a remote-assistance-eligible service, then follow our easy VPN  setup instructions, and one of our experts will connect to your computer over our encrypted virtual network!

If you have a problem which requires a service that is not listed on our website, please contact us and we will do our best to solve it, even if that means referring you to one of our competitors.

fields.title: Privacy Policy
fields.content:
This privacy policy discloses the privacy practices for www.alphageek.xyz. This privacy policy applies solely to information collected by this web site. It will notify you of the following:

  1. What personally identifiable information is collected from you through the web site, how it is used and with whom it may be shared.
  2. What choices are available to you regarding the use of your data.
  3. The security procedures in place to protect the misuse of your information.
  4. How you can correct any inaccuracies in the information.

Information Collection, Use, and Sharing

We are the sole owners of the information collected on this site. We only have access to/collect information that you voluntarily give us via email or other direct contact from you. We will not sell or rent this information to anyone.

We will use your information to respond to you, regarding the reason you contacted us. We will not share your information with any third party outside of our organization, other than as necessary to fulfill your request, e.g. to ship an order.

Unless you ask us not to, we may contact you via email in the future to tell you about specials, new products or services, or changes to this privacy policy.

Your Access to and Control Over Information

You may opt out of any future contacts from us at any time. You can do the following at any time by contacting us via the email address or phone number given on our website:

  • See what data we have about you, if any.
  • Change/correct any data we have about you.
  • Have us delete any data we have about you.
  • Express any concern you have about our use of your data.

Security

We take precautions to protect your information. When you submit sensitive information via the website, your information is protected both online and offline.

Wherever we collect sensitive information (such as credit card data), that information is encrypted and transmitted to us in a secure way. You can verify this by looking for a closed lock icon at the bottom of your web browser, or looking for "https" at the beginning of the address of the web page.

While we use encryption to protect sensitive information transmitted online, we also protect your information offline. Only employees who need the information to perform a specific job (for example, billing or customer service) are granted access to personally identifiable information. The computers/servers in which we store personally identifiable information are kept in a secure environment.

Updates

Our Privacy Policy may change from time to time and all updates will be posted on this page.

Cookies

We use "cookies" on this site. A cookie is a piece of data stored on a site visitor's hard drive to help us improve your access to our site and identify repeat visitors to our site. For instance, when we use a cookie to identify you, you would not have to log in a password more than once, thereby saving time while on our site. Cookies can also enable us to track and target the interests of our users to enhance the experience on our site. Usage of a cookie is in no way linked to any personally identifiable information on our site.

If you feel that we are not abiding by this privacy policy, you should contact us immediately via telephone at (972) 656-9338 or by email (root@alphageek.xyz).

fields.title: DO Sample Article
fields.content:
How To Install & Maintain Free TLS certificates Using acmetool with Nginx

Introduction

Let’s Encrypt is a free, automated, and open Certificate Authority that makes it possible to set up an HTTPS server and have it automatically obtain a browser-trusted certificate, without any human intervention. This is accomplished by running an Acme Protocol-compliant certificate management agent on the web server. While there are many such tools available, including Let's Encrypt's own "certbot", not all are created equal. One program in particular, acmetool, is especially simple to configure and feature-rich.

This tutorial provides instructions for the installation and maintenance of TLS certificates using "acmetool". Upon completion, users should have a valid, automatically-renewing certificate that is trusted by most modern web browsers.

Due to acmetool's built-in web server and ability to adapt to available challenge methods, an existing web server isn't necessary for development purposes. However, given that a TLS certificate serves no practical purpose without a method by which to serve it, reader's of this article will hence configure Nginx to reverse-proxy challenge requests to a non-privileged acmetool process listening on an internal port.

Note: While acmetool does maintain repositories for Ubuntu-, Debian-, and RPM-based distributions, the intent of this tutorial is to maintain cross-platform applicability. Users of any Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, FreeBSD, or CentOS droplet can follow this tutorial with minimal substitutions, the most likely of which being Nginx configuration file locations.

Prerequisites

Although this article applies to many platforms and architectures, it assumes the following prerequisites for the sake of simplicity and readability.

  • A fresh Ubuntu 16.04 (64-bit) instance. You can learn how to set this up by following this initial server setup guide

  • A domain name with nameservers pointed to DigitalOcean nameservers (refer to this tutorial).

  • A web server listening on port 80 (optional). This tutorial assumes a basic Nginx setup, such as the one explained here.

Note: Ensure that the "sudo" package is installed (If using a distro other than the above requisite). It is required internally by acmetool.

Step 1 — Login as Root

ssh root@example.com

Step 2 - Download and install acmetool

wget "https://github.com/hlandau/acme/releases/download/v${acmever:=0.0.58}/acmetool-v${acmever}-${ostype:=linux}_${arch:=amd64}.tar.gz"
tar xf "acmetool-v${acmever}-${ostype}_${arch}.tar.gz"
cp "acmetool-v${acmever}-${ostype}_${arch}/bin/acmetool" /usr/local/bin

Step 3 — Add and Configure "acme" User

useradd -mU acme
mkdir -p ~acme/lib/acme ~acme/hooks
chown acme:acme -R ~acme
chmod 0750 ~acme/lib/acme ~acme/hooks

Step 4 — Run acmetool quickstart

sudo -u acme acmetool --state ~acme/lib/acme --hooks ~acme/hooks quickstart

You will be asked a series of questions. For the sake of this tutorial, use the following values.

  1. Enter "1" for live certificates.
  2. Enter "2" for PROXY method.
  3. Enter "y" to accept the Terms of Use.
  4. (Optionally) Enter your email address. If you choose to provide an email, you will be notified about expiring certificates, as well as other useful information about Let's Encrypt.

Note: For in-depth explainations of the various options, please refer to the acmetool userguide.

col-md-offset-2"><div class="well well-lg bg-info"><h1 id="how-to-install-maintain-free-tls-certificates-using-acmetool-with-nginx">How To Install & Maintain Free TLS certificates Using acmetool with Nginx</h1><h3 id="introduction">Introduction</h3><p><a href="https://letsencrypt.org/how-it-works/">Let’s Encrypt</a> is a free, automated, and open Certificate Authority that makes it possible to set up an HTTPS server and have it automatically obtain a browser-trusted certificate, without any human intervention. This is accomplished by running an Acme Protocol-compliant certificate management agent on the web server. While there are many such tools available, including Let's Encrypt's own "certbot", not all are created equal. One program in particular, <a href="https://hlandau.github.io/acme/">acmetool</a>, is especially simple to configure and feature-rich.</p><p>This tutorial provides instructions for the installation and maintenance of TLS certificates using "acmetool". Upon completion, users should have a valid, automatically-renewing certificate that is trusted by most modern web browsers.</p><p>Due to acmetool's built-in web server and ability to adapt to available challenge methods, an existing web server isn't necessary for development purposes. However, given that a TLS certificate serves no practical purpose without a method by which to serve it, reader's of this article will hence configure Nginx to reverse-proxy challenge requests to a non-privileged acmetool process listening on an internal port.</p><p><strong>Note:</strong> While acmetool does maintain repositories for Ubuntu-, Debian-, and RPM-based distributions, the intent of this tutorial is to maintain cross-platform applicability. Users of any Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, FreeBSD, or CentOS droplet can follow this tutorial with minimal substitutions, the most likely of which being Nginx configuration file locations.</p><h2 id="prerequisites">Prerequisites</h2><p>Although this article applies to many platforms and architectures, it assumes the following prerequisites for the sake of simplicity and readability.</p><ul><li><p>A fresh Ubuntu 16.04 (64-bit) instance. You can learn how to set this up by following <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/initial-server-setup-with-ubuntu-16-04">this initial server setup guide</a></p></li><li><p>A domain name with nameservers pointed to DigitalOcean nameservers (refer to <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-set-up-a-host-name-with-digitalocean">this tutorial</a>).</p></li><li><p>A web server listening on port 80 (<strong>optional</strong>). This tutorial assumes a basic Nginx setup, such as the one explained <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-nginx-on-ubuntu-16-04">here</a>.</p></li></ul><p><strong>Note:</strong> Ensure that the "sudo" package is installed (If using a distro other than the above requisite). It is required internally by acmetool.</p><h2 id="step-1-login-as-root">Step 1 — Login as Root</h2><pre class="editor-colors lang-command"><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>ssh root@example.com</span></span></div></pre><h2 id="step-2-download-and-install-acmetool">Step 2 - Download and install acmetool</h2><pre class="editor-colors lang-super_user"><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>wget "</span><span class="markup underline link https hyperlink"><span>https://github.com/hlandau/acme/releases/download/v</span></span><span>${acmever:=0.0.58}/acmetool-v${acmever}-${ostype:=linux}_${arch:=amd64}.tar.gz"</span></span></div><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>tar xf "acmetool-v${acmever}-${ostype}_${arch}.tar.gz"</span></span></div><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>cp "acmetool-v${acmever}-${ostype}_${arch}/bin/acmetool" /usr/local/bin</span></span></div></pre><h2 id="step-3-add-and-configure-acme-user">Step 3 — Add and Configure "acme" User</h2><pre class="editor-colors lang-super_user"><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>useradd -mU acme</span></span></div><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>mkdir -p ~acme/lib/acme ~acme/hooks</span></span></div><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>chown acme:acme -R ~acme</span></span></div><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>chmod 0750 ~acme/lib/acme ~acme/hooks</span></span></div></pre><h2 id="step-4-run-acmetool-quickstart">Step 4 — Run acmetool quickstart</h2><pre class="editor-colors lang-super_user"><div class="line"><span class="text plain null-grammar"><span>sudo -u acme acmetool --state ~acme/lib/acme --hooks ~acme/hooks quickstart</span></span></div></pre><p>You will be asked a series of questions. For the sake of this tutorial, use the following values.</p><ol><li>Enter "1" for live certificates.</li><li>Enter "2" for PROXY method.</li><li>Enter "y" to accept the Terms of Use.</li><li>(Optionally) Enter your email address. If you choose to provide an email, you will be notified about expiring certificates, as well as other useful information about Let's Encrypt.</li></ol><p><strong>Note:</strong> For in-depth explainations of the various options, please refer to the <a href="https://hlandau.github.io/acme/userguide">acmetool userguide</a>.</p></div></div></div></div></body></html>
